security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing architectural guidelines. The static findings are all false positives triggered by pattern matching on benign content. The skill-report.json contains standard metadata (URLs, hashes) and the SKILL.md contains markdown documentation with code examples for educational purposes. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or command execution exists.

content.value_statement: Poor architecture leads to technical debt and difficult maintenance. This skill provides SOLID principles and Clean Architecture patterns to help you build maintainable, testable systems from the start.
actual_capabilities: Apply SOLID principles to class and module design
Structure code using Clean Architecture layers
Implement early return and clean code patterns
Make architectural decisions with a checklist
Separate concerns across domain, application, and infrastructure
limitations: Does not generate code implementations automatically
Does not analyze existing codebase structure
Does not provide framework-specific architecture templates
Does not execute or test code

use_cases.title: Design New Features
use_cases.description: Apply Clean Architecture when designing new features to ensure maintainable code structure.

use_cases.title: Review Architecture
use_cases.description: Evaluate proposed solutions against SOLID principles and architectural best practices.

use_cases.title: Fix Legacy Code
use_cases.description: Identify anti-patterns and apply separation of concerns to legacy codebases.

prompt_templates.title: New Feature Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a new feature using Clean Architecture. Show how to separate domain, application, and infrastructure layers. Apply SOLID principles. Include early return patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Code Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for SOLID principle violations. Identify God Classes, nested conditionals, and incorrect dependency direction. Suggest specific refactoring.

prompt_templates.title: Anti-Pattern Fix
prompt_templates.prompt: This code has deep nesting and mixed concerns. Refactor using early return pattern and separate into appropriate layers with domain-specific naming.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Decision
prompt_templates.prompt: Evaluate these three approaches for our use case. Consider dependency direction, testability, and separation of concerns. Use the decision checklist.

output_examples.input: Design a user authentication module with Clean Architecture
output: Domain Layer: User entity, UserRepository interface, AuthenticationService interface
Infrastructure Layer: UserRepositoryImpl, PasswordEncoder, JWT token generator
Presentation Layer: AuthController, AuthRequest DTO, AuthResponse DTO
Dependency Direction: All layers point inward to domain

output_examples.input: How do I structure a new Python project following Clean Architecture?
output: Domain Layer: models/ with pure business entities and exceptions
Application Layer: use_cases/ with business rule implementations
Infrastructure Layer: repositories/, services/ for external concerns
Presentation Layer: api/, cli/ for user interface
Avoid: Putting business logic in api/ or models/ mixed with infrastructure

output_examples.input: What are signs that a class violates Single Responsibility Principle?
output: Class name contains multiple concepts like UserHelperAuthFormatter
Methods don't share a common purpose or change frequency
Difficult to describe class responsibility in one sentence
Class requires changes when any of its features change
High cyclomatic complexity from managing multiple concerns

best_practices: Apply Single Responsibility Principle - each class has one clear purpose
Follow dependency rule - outer layers depend on inner layers, never reverse
Use domain-specific naming instead of generic names like utils or common
anti_patterns: NIH Syndrome - avoid reinventing wheels, prefer library solutions
God Class - split classes with too many responsibilities
Deep Nesting - use early return to flatten conditional logic

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Works with any LLM that follows system prompts.

faq.question: What is the maximum function size recommended?
faq.answer: Recommended 30 lines, maximum 50 lines. Functions over 50 lines should be split into smaller units.

faq.question: How do I integrate with my existing codebase?
faq.answer: Use this skill as a guide during design sessions. Apply principles incrementally to new code and refactoring tasks.

faq.question: Does this skill access my files or data?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-only skill that provides architectural guidance. It does not read, write, or execute any code.

faq.question: What if my framework has specific patterns?
faq.answer: Adapt Clean Architecture principles to your framework. The core concept of layered separation remains the same.

faq.question: How is this different from design patterns?
faq.answer: Design patterns solve specific problems. Architecture principles define overall structure. Use both together for maintainable code.
